On Monday 03 March 2003 20:59, Chuck Hinson wrote:
> I should note first, that I'm a bit confused where this thread is going.
>  It seems to me that we started by bitching about how browsers aren't
> terribly helpful with HTTP authentication.  Somehow, we've ending up
> talking about capabilities-based security,

The link between the two topics is that HTTP Authentication is
also not terribly helpful for implementing access control.
Switching to capabilities improves your GUI, your application
design and your security.

> which you have already
> indicated isn't really the best choice for the majority of what's on the
> web today.

That is not the impression I intended to convey. Capability-based
security is the best choice for implementing access control. Both
capabilities *and* ACLs fail to implement DRM, so you might as
well stick with ACLs for DRM hacks. (More on this at the end of
the message.)

> I think part of the problem I have is that with a capability model, it
> seems that you end up with everyone having their own private web of
> resources rather than having a public web of resources that are sharable
> with others.

Well, that's kinda the whole point of access control isn't it? Do
you want your bank account to be part of the public web of
resources?  If so, please send me the first link. ;)

The point of access control is to create private webs of
resources, with finely controlled links between them. Capabilities
are an excellent tool for implementing this.

> As a result, you've lost the ability for people to connect
> those resources together in new ways to create new things on the web.

Exactly the opposite.  What you've done is empowered people to
securely connect those resource that they want connected. The ACL
model prevents this.

Just as an example, why don't you post to this list a link to a
withdrawal record from your online bank account. With the current
interface, this is not possible: you can't do it without also
posting the password for your entire account. If your bank account
was implemented with a capability-based security model, posting
the withdrawal record link would be no problem.  Capabilities
enable you to create links.  ACLs prevent you from creating links.

> >There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
> >issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
> >program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
> >to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
> >doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
> >variable.
>
> I'm not sure I'd agree that "web services" is about program to program
> communication.  I'm sure there are a lot of "web services" where there's
> only a program at one end and some things that look like documents or
> document processors at the other end.  "Program-to-program
> communication" the way you  seem to be using it sounds a lot like an RPC
> model to me, and in my mind REST and RPC don't mix.

Is it your contention that program to program communication is RPC
and therefore not REST? If so, this has grave implications for any
thoughts of business integration with REST.

My only point from the quoted paragraph is that browser GUI issues
do not apply to software integration through REST.

> >It's also easy to implement "navigate back" from within a web
> >browser interface to the application. The simplest answer is just:
> >"Use the 'back' button to navigate 'back'.".
>
> This is an example of poor usability.

In which case the more sophisticated techniques I layed out next
are appropriate.

> Further, what if I've got that page bookmarked?

Bookmark the page that you want to bookmark. If you want to
bookmark the top level page, bookmark the top level page.

> So how do you establish an initial context (or whatever its called) in a
> capability-based system without doing authentication?

Your initial context is whatever set of URIs you start with. If
your program is an XSLT stylesheet, your initial context is the
set of URIs in the input XML document.

> >>If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
> >>at the same time allow users to refer to the same
> >>document?
> >
> >You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
> >the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
> >not use the capability model to solve this problem.
>
> I'm not disagreeing, but how about giving an example of something
> (web-based) that you would use a capability model to solve.

I did. Your web-based bank account.

> >There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
> >just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
> >control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
> >problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
> >problems, not DRM problems.
>
> Well, you may just have go into your long explanation, because if DRM
> isn't about controlling access, then I'm pretty confused.

Access control is about controlling what authority you hand out.
DRM is about controlling how people use authority they have
already been given.

In the WSJ scenario, a subscribed user is given the authority to
read WSJ articles. The read authority implicitly carries with it
the authority to pass-on the article to others. If you can read
bits, you can copy bits. Neither capabilities nor ACLs can prevent
you from giving a WSJ article to someone who is not a WSJ
subscriber. The best you can do is make it less convenient to
share the article. That is all the WSJ ACL does. It is just a
feeble DRM measure.

Fortunately, business integration and trading is about access
control, not DRM. Capabilities are ideal for this.

Tyler
